contents.title: Get started
contents.description:
ViewTube is a self-hostable frontend for YouTube. If you do not want to install it yourself, you can use one of the public instances.:br
If you have a server or PC to run it on, check out the installation guide.

children.value: ViewTube is a self-hostable frontend for YouTube. If you do not want to install it yourself, you can use one of the

.:br
If you have a server or PC to run it on, check out the
This instance uses the latest stable version.
You can add your instance to this list by
ViewTube is an alternative YouTube frontend that lets you watch, search and discover YouTube videos without ads or tracking.

contents.title: Installation
contents.description: Currently there are two ways to install ViewTube:

children.value: Currently there are two ways to install ViewTube:
ViewTube can be run in a Docker container. You will need to have
is the latest stable version. It should generally be safe to use. If you don't want to update automatically, you can use the version tag directly.
is the development version, which means it may contain bugs. However, it will receive fixes faster if YouTube changes something.
for more information about the environment variables.
For the purpose of this guide, we will use the following environment variables:
Create a folder for your ViewTube instance.

props.code:
version: '3'

services:
  viewtube:
    restart: unless-stopped
    # Or use mauriceo/viewtube:dev for the development version
    image: mauriceo/viewtube:latest
    # ViewTube will not start until the database and redis are ready
    depends_on:
      - viewtube-mongodb
      - viewtube-redis
    # Make sure all services are in the same network
    networks:
      - viewtube
    volumes:
      # This will map ViewTube's data directory to the local folder ./data/viewtube/
      - ./data/viewtube:/data
    environment:
      - VIEWTUBE_DATABASE_HOST=viewtube-mongodb
      - VIEWTUBE_REDIS_HOST=viewtube-redis
    ports:
      - 8066:8066

  viewtube-mongodb:
    restart: unless-stopped
    image: mongo:7
    networks:
      - viewtube
    volumes:
      - ./data/db:/data/db

  viewtube-redis:
    restart: unless-stopped
    image: redis:7
    networks:
      - viewtube
    volumes:
      - ./data/redis:/data

networks:
  viewtube:

children.value: # Or use mauriceo/viewtube:dev for the development version
# ViewTube will not start until the database and redis are ready
# Make sure all services are in the same network
# This will map ViewTube's data directory to the local folder ./data/viewtube/
Running on systems without AVX support, e.g. Synology NAS
When running on a home NAS system, e.g. Synlogy, QNAP, ASUSTOR, etc., you may encounter the following warning:

props.code:
viewtube-mongodb    | WARNING: MongoDB 5.0+ requires a CPU with AVX support, and your current system does not appear to have that!
viewtube-mongodb    |   see https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/SERVER-54407
viewtube-mongodb    |   see also https://www.mongodb.com/community/forums/t/mongodb-5-0-cpu-intel-g4650-compatibility/116610/2
viewtube-mongodb    |   see also https://github.com/docker-library/mongo/issues/485#issuecomment-891991814

children.value: made an all-in-one image of ViewTube. Check it out here:

ViewTube will check all required environment variables on startup. Check the logs to see if any are missing!
The hostname of the redis instance
The port of the redis instance
The password of the redis instance
Instruct ViewTube to start as many worker processes as it has threads available. If disabled, it will run on a single process instance.
Specify the domain allowed to make cross-origin requests to ViewTube (see:
Enables some security features (CSP headers, secure cookies). Enable this if you are using an HTTPS certificate
The admin account of this instance (see:
The URL of the proxy server (see:
Specify the time between subscription refreshes in minutes.
Specify the location for the trending page. For example, "DE" for Germany.

environment variable specifies the domains that are allowed to access the resources served by ViewTube.
For example, if you set VIEWTUBE_CORS_ORIGIN to
will be allowed to access the api of your ViewTube instance.

By default, CORS is disabled. In Production, it is recommended to set VIEWTUBE_CORS_ORIGIN to the domain that you are accessing your instance from.
Read more about CORS here:

props.code:
# redis.conf

maxmemory 4GB # Set the maximum memory Redis can use
maxmemory-policy allkeys-lru # Set the eviction policy (Read more here https://redis.io/docs/latest/operate/rs/databases/memory-performance/eviction-policy/)

children.value:
# redis.conf

maxmemory 4GB # Set the maximum memory Redis can use
maxmemory-policy allkeys-lru # Set the eviction policy (Read more here https://redis.io/docs/latest/operate/rs/databases/memory-performance/eviction-policy/)
Make the following changes to your docker-compose file.

props.code:
# docker-compose.yml

redis:
  ...
  volumes:
    ...
    - ./config/redis.conf:/redis.conf # Add the redis.conf file to the container
  command: ["redis-server", "/redis.conf"] # Start Redis with the custom configuration
  ...

children.value: # Add the redis.conf file to the container
# Start Redis with the custom configuration
YouTube rate-limits and blocks IPs sometimes, if they detect too many requests from the same IP. There are a few ways to circumvent this.
Use cookies from a real account
You can provide your own cookies to circumvent this issue.
Navigate to YouTube in a web browser
Log in, preferrably with a separate account you don't use often
Open up the dev tools console
Copy the entire response into the
Another way to circumvent Google's rate-limiting is to use an external proxy. ViewTube already proxies all requests through the server it's running on, but you can also use an external proxy.
Set the proxy URL using the

links.text: Use cookies from a real account

children.value: The admin account is disabled by default.
In order to enable it, set the environment variable
to the username of the account to be used as admin. Afterwards, restart ViewTube.
Set the environment variable only after you've created the account, otherwise anyone could create that account and receive administrative privileges.
Learn how to use the admin panel in

contents.title: Recovery
contents.description: This page is a collection of remedies for issues that can occur with ViewTube.

children.value: This page is a collection of remedies for issues that can occur with ViewTube.
Create a new account you would like to use as an admin
to your the username of your new account
If have registration disabled and cannot create an account, continue reading.
Disabled registration and lost access to admin account
Start a shell session inside the mongodb container
Execute the following command to allow registration
Now you can create a new admin user according to the topic above.

contents.title: Features
contents.description: This section of the documentation provides an overview of some of the features of ViewTube.

children.value: This section of the documentation provides an overview of some of the features of ViewTube.
Click on "Next step", then click on "Create export"
Once you have received the data, download it and extract the .zip-file
Find the file "subscriptions.csv" and upload it to ViewTube

Each time you log in with a new browser or device, a session is created. It is stored in a cookie and is valid for 7 days. This session is extended each time you visit ViewTube. If you do not visit ViewTube for 7 days, the session expires and you are automatically logged out.
The sessions explained above are referred to as "devices" on your profile page (
). Your active device is highlighted with a border.

You can rename devices and choose a different icon for them.
You can remove a device, which must then log in again.

contents.title: Admin Panel
contents.description: Visit the admin panel by clicking on your profile image and selecting "Admin panel".

children.value: Visit the admin panel by clicking on your profile image and selecting "Admin panel".
Information about the server and configuration. Only IP adress is shown at the moment, more coming soon.
Configure options for the instance here. Make sure to restart ViewTube after configuring these options.
If this option is disabled, the register form is hidden and registration is blocked. Accounts can only be created by the admin.
Makes the entire ViewTube instance private, requiring a login for every page.
Look for the following log messages to make sure your preferred configuration is applied.
View and download the log files.
This option allows adding video IDs that wil be blocked. This option exists in order for public instances to respond to DMCA requests. Make sure to only add the ID of the video, not the entire URL.
If blocked, a video will show the following error when accessed.

contents.title: Get started
contents.description:
You can develop on basically any system that supports the prerequisites.
I personally develop on Windows and Linux. If you find that the development setup is not working for you, please submit a pull request. Unfortunately i don't have the time to test on every system. However, this documentation should be a pretty good starting point.

children.value: You can develop on basically any system that supports the

.
I personally develop on Windows and Linux. If you find that the development setup is not working for you, please
. Unfortunately i don't have the time to test on every system. However, this documentation should be a pretty good starting point.
For development, you need the following tools installed.
Of course, the basics like a text editor, git and a terminal are also required.
If you want to contribute to ViewTube, I'd recommend you to fork the repository first. Otherwise, you can just clone it.
Run the development environment with docker
In order to run the server, you also need MongoDB and Redis. There is a docker-compose file supplied to run these locally. To use it, you need to have docker and docker-compose installed.
Run the following command at the root of the project to start MongoDB and Redis

If you don't want to use docker, you need to install MongoDB and Redis separately.
ViewTube will automatically connect to the default ports of these services. If yours are different, check the
page on how to change them.
Run the following command at the root of the project to install all dependencies.
In order to run the server and client, you need to run the following commands in two separate terminals:
